description: Cap 2-7 cm tall with distinctive honeycomb pattern of irregular pits and ridges, yellow-brown in color. Stem 2-9 cm long, hollow, white to yellow. Entire structure completely hollow from cap through stem.
habitat: Found under hardwoods (elm, ash, oak) and conifers in rich, non-acidic soil. Prefers disturbed areas, old orchards, and recently burned sites.
season: Southern US: March-April, Midwest: April-May, Northeast: May-June. Peak around Mother's Day in many regions.
lookalikes: Gyromitra esculenta (False Morel) - DEADLY - brain-like wrinkled cap instead of honeycomb pattern
Verpa species (Thimble Caps) - POISONOUS - cap partially attached to stem with cotton-like tissue inside
safety_notes: Must be cooked before consumption, toxic when raw. Always cut vertically to verify completely hollow interior. Risk of confusion with deadly false morels requires 100% certain identification.
